subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order
msgSnippet: ... LOT.  LOT = PALM for me, but it can t be PALM because of the TO. ... Do you mean actually says it is in PALM, or writes it with [A:]? The rather
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> So which lexical set does "bomb" belong to?

LOT. LOT = PALM for me, but it can't be PALM because of the TO.

> in either the LOT or the THOUGHT set, but not in the PALM set. My
> Longhorn dictionary puts it in the PALM set, however, which means it
> should be spelled with Ah, and that looks odd to me.

Do you mean actually says it is in PALM, or writes it with [A:]?
The rather old-fashioned "General American" of dictionaries,
which doesn't reflect THOUGHT = PALM, never mind later distinctions,
generally uses the same symbol for LOT and PALM.

> Also, under the current scheme, British have a different set for LOT and
> THOUGHT. Under the new schemed, the merge these two. But I thought most
> British keep these sets separate?

RP, at least, definitely keeps them separate: LOT = CLOTH, THOUGHT, and
PALM are all different.

--
Schlingt dreifach einen Kreis vom dies! John Cowan <cowan@...>
Schliesst euer Aug vor heiliger Schau, http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
Denn er genoss vom Honig-Tau,
Und trank die Milch vom Paradies. -- Coleridge (tr. Politzer)

> in either the LOT or the THOUGHT set, but not in the PALM set. My 
> Longhorn dictionary puts it in the PALM set, however, which means it 
> should be spelled with Ah, and that looks odd to me.

Do you mean actually says it is in PALM, or writes it with [A:]?
The rather old-fashioned "General American" of dictionaries,
which doesn't reflect THOUGHT = PALM, never mind later distinctions,
generally uses the same symbol for LOT and PALM.

> Also, under the current scheme, British have a different set for LOT and 
> THOUGHT. Under the new schemed, the merge these two. But I thought most 
> British keep these sets separate?

RP, at least, definitely keeps them separate:  LOT = CLOTH, THOUGHT, and
PALM are all different.
